SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings using context, affixes, or reference materials.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:“I can't believe how a͟u͟t͟h͟e͟n͟t͟i͟c some of those costumes looked,” replied Eric.
Which meaning of the word a͟u͟t͟h͟e͟n͟t͟i͟c is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: reliable; trustworthy

B.Choice: genuine; resembling an original

C.Choice: representing true nature or beliefs

D.Choice: supported by unquestionable evidence

SubTopics: Analyze how the setting, characters, and plot of a text affect each other and contribute to meaning.
Content: Match each statement with the correct character's name to show how each character's actions contribute to the meaning of the passage.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: The author contrasts Tom's point of view with Becky's point of view by describing the different ways that Tom and Becky

A.Choice: search for an appropriate costume.

B.Choice: learn about the festival events.

C.Choice: interact with other characters.

D.Choice: compete in the contest.

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the BEST explanation for why Tom is unsure about seeing Becky?

A.Choice: He has other friends.

B.Choice: Becky acts disinterested.

C.Choice: He is not sure he will like Becky anymore.

D.Choice: Becky is often busy helping her parents with chores.

Content: Which sentences from the passage BEST support the answer to part A? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: He saw Becky only once a year.

B.Choice: Last year Becky spent so much time texting that her parents imposed a new policy: no more than one hour each day on electronic devices.

C.Choice: With a half-hearted smile, Becky hugged Tom's parents.

D.Choice: Becky stuffed her hands into the pockets of her jeans.

E.Choice: Tom, Becky, and Eric decided they would search inside their RVs to see what they could find.

SubTopics: Using appropriate text, determine the theme(s) of a text and explain the relationship between the theme(s) and supporting evidence; summarize the text distinct from personal opinions.
Content: Read the summary of the passage.

:ibox:Three families vacation at a campground that is hosting an event called National Tom Sawyer Days. When Becky arrives, she reluctantly goes with Tom to find Eric. Eric tells Tom and Becky about a fence-painting contest. In spite of losing, the families have so much fun that they decide to come back every year.
Which key events are missing? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: The kids dress up in their costumes and go to the park to participate in the contest.

B.Choice: Tom explains to Becky that there will be live entertainment and fireworks.

C.Choice: Eric learns that Tom and Becky were named after characters in the Tom Sawyer books.

D.Choice: Two boys, Tom and Eric, become friends after tossing a baseball back and forth with each other.

E.Choice: Tom explains to Eric that, every year, Tom's and Becky's families go on a camping trip together.

SubTopics: Evaluate an author's argument, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which excerpt from the passage BEST supports the author's claim that film composers must have a special personality?

A.Choice: ... work together quickly and be prepared to make changes to how their final product sounds.

B.Choice: ... can share computer files with the director during the production process.

C.Choice: ... might weave together four or five “themes,” or melodies.

D.Choice: ... to communicate ideas in the film with music.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative, connotative, and content-specific meanings using context, affixes, or reference materials.
Content: Choose the underlined word that means “to incorporate or contain as an essential part or characteristic.”

A full-length movie :MC-A: r͟e͟q͟u͟i͟r͟e͟s about an hour's worth of music. The composer might weave together four or five “themes,” or melodies. Often, these melodies are :MC-B: a͟s͟s͟o͟c͟i͟a͟t͟e͟d with important places or characters in the story. These melodies :MC-C: o͟c͟c͟u͟r repeatedly, perhaps on different instruments and maybe with sung lyrics. A listener might notice sound effects :MC-D: e͟m͟b͟e͟d͟d͟e͟d in the music, such as a “crash” of piano keys as something hits the floor. A surprising harmony might go along with a surprise on the screen. The film composer's job is sometimes to :MC-E: c͟o͟m͟m͟u͟n͟i͟c͟a͟t͟e ideas in the film with music.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops his/her point of view or purpose and distinguishes it from those of others.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
With which statement would the author MOST LIKELY agree?

A.Choice: A film must use music created by expert musicians to be successful.

B.Choice: Those who compose music for movies should be paid as much as a director.

C.Choice: The music in a movie can fundamentally alter the meaning of a segment of the plot.

D.Choice: Anyone with an interest in music can gain employment in the movie-music industry.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: With this genre, all possible forms of music can come together to set the tone for each scene in a film.

B.Choice: They may work with singers, instrumentalists, or even an entire orchestra.

C.Choice: In earlier years of moviemaking, a film composer received a script, wrote music, and supervised a recording.

D.Choice: However, there are plenty of film composers who are self-taught or who work entirely on computers.

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read the inference.
:ibox:Becoming a film composer is a difficult task.
Which pieces of evidence from the passage BEST support the inference? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: A composer can work with a director to decide which music clips to use in a film.

B.Choice: A composer learns about a variety of music and may have extensive training as a musician.

C.Choice: A composer uses melodies that may be related to certain settings or characters in a story.

D.Choice: A composer may work for years in different jobs before getting to write music for a movie.

E.Choice: A composer may write things down while watching and listening to a movie.

SubTopics: Explain the central/main idea(s) of a text and explain the relationship between the central idea(s) and supporting evidence; summarize the text distinct from personal opinions.
Content: Which sentences BEST express the central ideas of the passage? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: Music adds an important element to films.

B.Choice: Movies rely on various forms of music to create moods.

C.Choice: People who create memorable music often win prestigious awards.

D.Choice: Composing movie music is a challenging career that contributes great artistic value.

E.Choice: A person must first have classical training on an instrument to create music for films.

SubTopics: Explain how characters and settings reflect historical and/or cultural contexts.
Content: “Road Trip” is set in 1953. How does Harry S Truman's character in the passage reflect this historical time period?

A.Choice: Harry is on a long trip.

B.Choice: Harry misses his chauffeur.

C.Choice: Harry is photographed for newspapers.

D.Choice: Harry is amazed by the latest technology in his car.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the points of view of different characters or narrators in a text.
Content: How does the author develop the differences in the points of view of Bess and Harry S Truman?

A.Choice: by including their dialogue during the trip

B.Choice: by stating their reactions to the heat

C.Choice: by explaining their past occupations

D.Choice: by describing their attire in detail

SubTopics: Analyze how specific word choices contribute to meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:ibox:“Come now, Harry,” Bess said. “It certainly isn't that complicated, is it?”
Which words BEST express the tone created by Bess's word choice in the sentences? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: dismissive

B.Choice: gloomy

C.Choice: impatient

D.Choice: knowledgeable

SubTopics: Analyze how a text's form or overall structure contributes to meaning.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Identify the overall structure of the passage.

A.Choice: compare and contrast

B.Choice: cause and effect

C.Choice: description

D.Choice: chronology

Content: Identify how the structure from Part A contributes to the meaning of the passage.

E.Choice: tells the story of their drive through Pennsylvania

F.Choice: uses vivid language to detail the setting of the state of Missouri

G.Choice: explains the connection between leaving Missouri and arriving in Pennsylvania

H.Choice: outlines the similarities and differences between Harry S Truman and other presidents

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings using context, affixes, or reference materials.
Content: Choose the two underlined phrases that provide clues to the meaning of the word signaled as it is used in the passage.

As the couple :MC-A: c͟o͟n͟t͟i͟n͟u͟e͟d͟ ͟d͟r͟i͟v͟i͟n͟g in the left lane on the stretch of highway near Bedford, Pennsylvania, they :MC-B: p͟a͟i͟d͟ ͟n͟o͟ ͟a͟t͟t͟e͟n͟t͟i͟o͟n to the line of cars :MC-C: f͟o͟l͟l͟o͟w͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟m. However, they were :MC-D: b͟o͟t͟h͟ ͟s͟u͟r͟p͟r͟i͟s͟e͟d when a state trooper :MC-E: p͟u͟l͟l͟e͟d͟ ͟u͟p͟ ͟a͟l͟o͟n͟g͟s͟i͟d͟e them in the right lane. The trooper :MC-F: t͟u͟r͟n͟e͟d͟ ͟o͟n͟ ͟h͟i͟s͟ ͟f͟l͟a͟s͟h͟e͟r͟s and signaled Harry to pull over to the side of the road.

SubTopics: Evaluate an author's argument, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which sentence from “Real Life in the Classroom” provides the MOST relevant and sufficient evidence for the claim that taking practical types of classes may help students stay engaged in school?

A.Choice: They also need to develop independent thinking and problem-solving skills that appeal to future employers.

B.Choice: Capturing students' interest helps ensure that they will stay in school and graduate.

C.Choice: In fact, four out of five students who dropped out of school said they wanted more-interesting classes with real-life learning.

D.Choice: In Wisconsin, students study topics based on ideas that come directly from the students, such as family, community, and career.

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Based on “Real Life in the Classroom,” which inference can BEST be made about the merit of programs like those in North Carolina and Illinois?

A.Choice: They lead to students getting jobs with the companies they study.

B.Choice: They allow students to receive extra tutoring in academic subjects.

C.Choice: They allow students to have real-world experiences that will help them as adults.

D.Choice: They lead to students performing better in academic subjects while in high school.

Content: Which sentences from the passage provide the BEST evidence for the answer to part A? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: Many students achieve good grades throughout middle school and high school.

B.Choice: Yet, when they graduate, they are unable to cook a meal or create a spending budget.

C.Choice: Instead, courses focus mainly on academic subjects, like math, English, history, and science.

D.Choice: Based on their interests, students are paired with businesses and become familiar with the latest technology in the business world.

E.Choice: They expose students to a variety of different career options.

SubTopics: Explain the central/main idea(s) of a text and explain the relationship between the central idea(s) and supporting evidence; summarize the text distinct from personal opinions.
Content: Which sentences BEST express the central ideas of “Academics in Middle School”? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: Middle schools should reduce the number of advanced classes that they offer.

B.Choice: Middle schools should work to develop more mentoring programs between teachers and students.

C.Choice: Middle schools should focus primarily on teaching core academic subjects, such as math, history, and science.

D.Choice: Middle school students should learn life skills such as cooking, budget writing, and woodworking at home or in community classes.

E.Choice: Middle school students should take additional courses in subjects such as art, music, and physical education before they enter high school.

SubTopics: Evaluate an author's argument, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Based on “Academics in Middle School,” which details BEST support the author's claim that it is impractical for schools to offer life-skill classes?

A.Choice: There are not enough rooms in each school or enough money to be able to offer life-skill classes.

B.Choice: There is not enough money in school budgets or time in the school day to support life-skill classes.

C.Choice: There is not enough time during the school day or student interest to offer life-skill classes.

D.Choice: There are not enough teachers certified for or students interested in life-skill classes.

SubTopics: Analyze how word choice contributes to meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from “Academics in Middle School.”
:ibox:Recently, teachers at this level have been p͟u͟s͟h͟e͟d to develop curricula that help students explore skills outside of the usual academic courses.
How does the word choice of p͟u͟s͟h͟e͟d contribute to the tone of the sentence?

A.Choice: It helps to create a friendly tone.

B.Choice: It helps to create a sense of urgency.

C.Choice: It helps to develop a questioning tone.

D.Choice: It helps to develop a sense of hopefulness.

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: Which clue can indicate that an online source is NOT credible?

A.Choice: links to websites that have been taken down

B.Choice: incomplete or missing copyright information

C.Choice: multiple authors contributing to the site

D.Choice: use of bright colors and fancy fonts

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: Students are trying to prove the claim that daily exercise helps people sleep better. Which research question would help them prove the claim?

A.Choice: How is sleep affected by activity?

B.Choice: How does exercise increase energy?

C.Choice: How does exercise help build muscle?

D.Choice: How many hours of sleep is best for students?

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student has written a draft paragraph from her research on automobiles, but the paragraph is overly broad. Read the paragraph.

:ibox:Henry Ford is understandably one of the most important figures in transportation history. His Model T car was the beginning of an entire lifestyle focused on driving. Cars can now be found all over the world. Every one of them, from compact cars to giant SUVs, are thanks to Ford. The Model T originally sold for only $850. The first production plant was in Detroit, Michigan, and the first car rolled off the assembly line in 1908. The assembly line was another of Ford's major contributions. To reduce the cost of making the cars, he created a system where people were responsible for building one part of the car. That part then moved along a conveyor belt where the next person would add his part. This system of specialized assembly continues today in plants across many different industries.
The student wants to narrow the topic of the paragraph. Which TWO research questions would help narrow the topic appropriately?

A.Choice: What does an assembly line look like?

B.Choice: How did the Model T change transportation?

C.Choice: How many original Model T cars exist today?

D.Choice: How did Ford contribute to the car industry?

E.Choice: Why did Ford build his production plant in Detroit?

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student is writing an argumentative report about the cost of hosting the Olympic Games. He found sources for his report. Indicate whether each source is relevant or not relevant to the topic.

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student took notes about computer viruses from two sources. Read the sources.

:ibox:Source A

Computer viruses pose a great risk to people of all ages. People rely on the Internet to find much of the information they need, so it is common to be fooled by a bad link or email attachment. Some viruses are easy to spot and fix, but others can damage a computer so badly that it needs to be replaced entirely.

:ibox:Source B

One of the best ways to protect against computer viruses is to use an antivirus program. These programs run whenever the computer is on. They often catch viruses the user did not even know were there. They will even give warning messages about dangerous websites and scan documents before they are downloaded.
Which sentence from the student's notes correctly paraphrases, or restates, information from BOTH sources?

A.Choice: People sometimes have to buy brand new computers because of a bad virus downloaded from the Internet.

B.Choice: Antivirus programs are important tools that warn the user when a computer virus is present.

C.Choice: Users of all ages can reduce the risk from computer viruses by using antivirus programs.

D.Choice: It is easy for someone to infect a computer with a virus when using email or the Internet.

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student is writing a report about using name-brand products in films. Read the source the student found.

:ibox:Source

Filmmakers have used name-brand products in their movies since 1919. The process has developed much since then. The method of choosing which brand to use has become an important part of movie production. The legal aspects of using brand names has created an entire legal industry. Film companies establish regulations that determine how a product is used in their films. They also decide on the financial terms with a brand's company. Brands often are secondary to the film, acting only as background or props. However, some products become central to the story. Some film companies choose to use fictitious products to avoid branding altogether.

The student wants to include information from the source in her report but does not want to plagiarize the author's ideas. Read the paragraph from the student's report. Choose the sentence in the paragraph that is plagiarized.

:MC-A: The art of using name-brand products in movies has been going on for about 100 years. :MC-B: There are many reasons to do this, including making money for the product's company. :MC-C: Filmmakers work closely with those companies to decide on how the money will be paid for using the product. :MC-D: There are many regulations for using products in films. :MC-E: Some production companies would rather use fictitious product names to avoid branding completely. :MC-F: However, there is nothing to suggest that branding will stop any time soon.

SubTopics: Choose appropriate, precise language for the style, task, and audience; convey the relationship among ideas through varied sentence structures.
Content: A student is writing a narrative for a creative writing class assignment. Read an excerpt from the draft.

:ibox:The wind swirled around Annaka, moving at a fevered pitch and roaring with the power of a thousand lions. Her mind raced as she thought through her options, but each one seemed as fruitless as the last. H͟e͟r͟ ͟h͟e͟a͟r͟t͟ ͟w͟a͟s͟ ͟b͟e͟a͟t͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟i͟n͟ ͟h͟e͟r͟ ͟c͟h͟e͟s͟t͟. Suddenly, she bolted upright and looked confusedly around her. She saw her phone, glowing on the nightstand, and her alarm clock proclaiming the time. She felt her bed, solid and secure, beneath her. “A dream,” she whispered. “It was just a dream.”
Which revision to the underlined sentence uses the MOST precise language for the style of writing?

A.Choice: Her heart kept pounding in her chest.

B.Choice: She could feel her heart beating against her chest.

C.Choice: Her heart beat furiously in her chest, thumping so hard she feared it would burst.

D.Choice: She sensed her heart deep in her chest, pounding rapidly and wildly like the storm around her.

SubTopics: Introduce the topic, maintain a clear focus throughout the text, and provide a conclusion that follows from the text. Add or delete content to clarify meaning.
Content: Read the draft from a student's report about color. Select the BEST introductory and concluding sentences for the paragraph?

:DD-1: Artists who work with paint often use the three primary colors: yellow, blue, and red. From those three colors, all other possible colors are created. To get shades of green, yellow and blue are mixed in different amounts. For purples, blue is mixed with red. On the other hand, light has different primary colors: red, green, and blue. Mixing red light with blue light still produces shades of purple, but green and red light becomes yellow! Even more interesting is how black and white are created in the different mediums. For paint, white is the absence of color, and black is all three colors combined. Light is the opposite. Combine red, green, and blue light to get white, while black is the absence of light. :DD-2:

1:A.Choice: Using paint and light to create colors can be difficult for artists.

1:B.Choice: It is surprising that a person can paint many colors by buying just three.

1:C.Choice: Color theory explains the effects of mixing color, most often with paint and light.

2:A.Choice: Of course, other colors are created through an endless variety of combinations.

2:B.Choice: No matter the medium, experimenting with color makes for a fascinating project.

2:C.Choice: Because of the differences between paint and light, more people prefer working with paint.

SubTopics: Choose appropriate, precise language for the style, task, and audience; convey the relationship among ideas through varied sentence structures.
Content: Read the paragraph from a student's draft of a letter to the editor of the school newspaper. Choose the sentences that should be revised to better match the style of the letter. Choose TWO answers.

:MC-A: I am deeply concerned about the recent cancellation of the upcoming lunchtime pep rally. :MC-B: I understand that the faculty is worried that students will be late to class after the rally. :MC-C: However, the rallies are an important part of developing school spirit. :MC-D: In addition, rallies are very cool, especially when kids get to join in. :MC-E: The events bring students together, and new friendships are often created. :MC-F: Indeed, the likelihood that two individuals might develop an everlasting bond is quite high. :MC-G: That's why I'm very disappointed that this month's rally was canceled. :MC-H: I certainly hope those in charge reconsider.

SubTopics: Use effective transitions to clarify relationships, connect ideas and claims, and signal time shifts.
Content: A student is writing an essay about going on a school field trip. Read the sentences from the essay. Choose the transitional word or phrase that BEST completes each sentence.

When going on a field trip, there is one tip you need to remember above all else: wear comfortable shoes. :DD-1: , students wear shoes that look good but are not appropriate for walking all day. As a result, students' feet become sore and tired. :DD-2: , students still have fun and look forward to the next field trip.

SubTopics: Introduce the topic, maintain a clear focus throughout the text, and provide a conclusion that follows from the text. Add or delete content to clarify meaning.
Content: Read a student's draft narrative.

:ibox:I had never taken pictures with anything other than my phone until I joined the yearbook club. The yearbook adviser outfitted me with a camera, gave me a brief lesson, and assigned me to my first project: capture the action at the student-versus-staff annual kickball game this coming Friday night. I was nervous and excited at the same time.

During the week, I decided it would be a good idea to practice taking pictures. My adviser gave me a few tips and told me to capture the ball and players in motion. Luckily, my sister had a softball game Wednesday night where I was able to practice using the camera. Taking action shots was harder than I had thought. I took several ordinary shots before I was able to master the action shots.

By Friday, I felt ready to represent the yearbook club at the kickball game. I took pictures of the students in the stands and our school mascot leading a cheer. I got a great action shot of Mr. Paris, the math teacher, diving to catch the ball. I also captured the game-winning play by the students at the end of the game! The students and the players celebrated their victory while I also celebrated mine.
Which sentence BEST concludes the last paragraph of the student's narrative?

A.Choice: I was glad the game was over and that the students had won the game.

B.Choice: I was happy that I had practiced taking pictures before the game.

C.Choice: I was now prepared to become the editor of the yearbook.

D.Choice: I was now confident and ready for my next assignment.

SubTopics: Acknowledge new information expressed by others including those presented in diverse media and, when warranted, modify their own views.
Content: According to recent studies, how can smelling rosemary help children?

A.Choice: It helps improve their schoolwork.

B.Choice: It helps them feel more positive.

C.Choice: It helps increase their creativity.

D.Choice: It helps them feel calm.

SubTopics: Acknowledge new information expressed by others including those presented in diverse media and, when warranted, modify their own views.
Content: According to the presentation, what are TWO benefits of listening to music before studying?

A.Choice: reduces anxiety

B.Choice: repairs memory

C.Choice: helps concentration

D.Choice: transfers information

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker's argument and claims, evaluating reasoning in order to pose questions that elicit elaboration and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant observations and ideas that bring the discussion back on topic as needed.
Content: How does the speaker present the evidence to support the claim in the presentation?

A.Choice: by describing various substitutions for studying

B.Choice: by comparing studying to other ways of learning information

C.Choice: by listing the reasons why people should try to learn to study

D.Choice: by explaining three activities that can help people study better

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker's argument and claims, evaluating reasoning in order to pose questions that elicit elaboration and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant observations and ideas that bring the discussion back on topic as needed.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which statement BEST expresses the speaker's claim?

A.Choice: Learning new things is a challenge.

B.Choice: Conducting research causes brain growth.

C.Choice: Spending time on projects improves your memory.

D.Choice: Doing some simple things can help you study more effectively.

Content: Which evidence from the presentation BEST supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: Exercising regularly and listening to music can help you focus.

B.Choice: Increased student success results when effective studying occurs.

C.Choice: Allowing your brain to function without stress makes studying easier.

D.Choice: Science fiction presents studying as a matter of plugging into a computer.

SubTopics: Acknowledge new information expressed by others including those presented in diverse media and, when warranted, modify their own views.
Content: According to the presentation, how can people help protect reefs?

A.Choice: by cleaning up trash on beaches

B.Choice: by supporting local tourism

C.Choice: by eating a variety of fish

D.Choice: by touching corals gently

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker's argument and claims, evaluating reasoning in order to pose questions that elicit elaboration and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant observations and ideas that bring the discussion back on topic as needed.
Content: Which detail does the speaker use to BEST provide evidence for the claim that coral reefs are important for sea life?

A.Choice: the number of fish supported by reefs

B.Choice: the color of creatures that live in reefs

C.Choice: the fact that reefs produce helpful chemicals

D.Choice: the way reefs contain colonies of individual animals

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker's argument and claims, evaluating reasoning in order to pose questions that elicit elaboration and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant observations and ideas that bring the discussion back on topic as needed.
Content: Which statement BEST expresses the speaker's claim in the presentation?

A.Choice: Coral reefs must be avoided by divers and snorkelers.

B.Choice: Coral reefs are composed of animals joined in a colony.

C.Choice: Coral reefs are the most diverse ecosystems in the world.

D.Choice: Coral reefs must be protected and preserved for the future.

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker's argument and claims, evaluating reasoning in order to pose questions that elicit elaboration and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant observations and ideas that bring the discussion back on topic as needed.
Content: What are the MAIN pieces of evidence the speaker provides to support the claim of the presentation? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: the economic costs of protecting coral reefs from humans

B.Choice: the benefits of coral reefs to sea life and humans

C.Choice: the natural and human threats to coral reefs

D.Choice: the definition and description of coral reefs

E.Choice: the number of species found in coral reefs
